title: 107_s1686
content: The Act titled "Safe Nursing and Patient Care Act of 2001" is cited as such. The Congress recognizes the importance of adequate nurse staffing levels for patient safety and outcomes. Despite evidence supporting this, there are challenges in recruiting and retaining nursing staff, leading to the use of mandatory overtime which contributes to nurse fatigue. Mandatory overtime contributes to nurse fatigue, leading to medical errors and compromising patient safety. Limitations on mandatory overtime will ensure public safety, quality healthcare services, and nurse retention/recruitment. SEC. 3. LIMITATIONS ON MANDATORY OVERTIME FOR NURSES. Provider agreements under the Social Security Act are amended to include limitations on mandatory overtime for nurses. This includes prohibiting nurses from working beyond their scheduled shift or more than 12 hours in a 24-hour period. The Social Security Act now includes limitations on mandatory overtime for nurses, restricting them from working beyond their scheduled shift or more than 12 hours in a 24-hour period. During a declared state of emergency, exceptions may apply for nurses providing an exceptional level of emergency medical services to the community, with certain limitations in place. During a declared state of emergency, nurses can work beyond their scheduled shift or more than 12 hours in a 24-hour period if they are providing emergency medical services. Nurses have the right to report violations of these provisions to the Secretary. During a state of emergency, nurses can work beyond their scheduled shift or more than 12 hours in a 24-hour period if providing emergency medical services. Nurses have the right to file complaints with the Secretary for violations, who will investigate and take actions against providers who violate nurse nondiscrimination protections. Nurses are protected from retaliation for refusing mandatory overtime or reporting violations of labor laws to regulatory agencies, accreditation bodies, or management. They can also participate in investigations without fear of reprisal. Employees, including health care professionals, are protected from retaliation for reporting violations of labor laws. Providers of services cannot file complaints against nurses who refuse mandatory overtime. Nurses are deemed to be acting in good faith if they believe the reported information is true and a violation has occurred. Providers of services must post a notice about these protections in a visible location. Providers of services must post a sign specifying nurses' rights, including the right to file complaints with the Secretary for violations. They must also post nurse schedules and can face a civil money penalty of up to $10,000 for each knowing violation. The Secretary may impose a civil money penalty of up to $10,000 for each knowing violation of the provisions, with more severe penalties for repeated violations. The names of providers facing penalties will be published on the Department of Health and Human Services website. The Department of Health and Human Services publishes names of providers facing civil money penalties for violations. Penalties imposed under previous ownership are not published after a 1-year period. Nurses can work more than specified hours if consistent with safe patient care standards. Mandatory overtime is defined as hours worked exceeding specified periods. In this subsection, definitions include mandatory overtime as hours worked exceeding specified periods with adverse consequences for nurses, overtime as time worked beyond specified periods, nurses defined as registered or licensed practical nurses, and providers of services as hospitals or hospital outpatient departments. The term 'services' refers to various healthcare facilities such as hospitals, outpatient departments, ambulatory surgical centers, home health agencies, rehabilitation agencies, clinics, and federally qualified health centers. A 'declared state of emergency' is an officially designated emergency declared by the Federal Government or appropriate state/local agency, excluding emergencies resulting from labor disputes in the healthcare industry. The term 'standards of safe patient care' refers to professional standards for nurses. The amendments in this section will take effect one year after the enactment of the Act. SEC. 4. REPORTS. The Secretary of Health and Human Services will conduct a study to establish safe working hour standards for nurses providing healthcare. The study will consider various factors and recommend maximum work hours. Additionally, a report on mandatory overtime in federally operated medical facilities will be conducted. The Director of the Office of Management and Budget will conduct a study on overtime practices for nurses in federally operated medical facilities. The report is due within 6 months of the Act's enactment. The Director of the Office of Management and Budget will submit a report to Congress within 6 months of the Act's enactment, including recommendations for implementing policies on overtime requirements for nurses in federally operated medical facilities.
